FEDERATION OF MALAYSIA


2.31 p.m.

    Order read for resuming adjourned debate.

    Mr Speaker: The Original Question, as amended, was:

    "That, in pursuance of the national objective of a united Malayan nation, enlarged and strengthened by the addition of our brothers in the Borneo territories, this House declares its support in principle for the plan proposed by the Prime Minister of the Federation of Malaya, Tunku Abdul Rahman Putra Al-Haj, and agreed to in principle in the Federation Parliament on 18th October, 1961, for the establishment of the Federation of Malaysia, comprising the eleven States of the present Federation, the States of Singapore and Brunei, and the territories of Sarawak and North Borneo.".

Since which amendments have been moved.

    In line 4, to leave out "plan" and insert "motion";

    In line 6, to leave out "in principle".

    The Question is, "That the word `plan' proposed to be left out, be left out." The debate will proceed on both amendments and the Original Question, as amended.

2.33 p.m.

    Mr Teo Hock Guan (Changi): Mr Speaker, Sir, I remember the Prime Minister of the Federation of Malaya said that he would not accept Singapore

Column: 750

into the Federation unless the three North Borneo territories were merged with the Federation. The fact is that if the three North Borneo territories are merged with Malaya and Singapore goes into the Federation with special status, i.e., the so-called partnership, the name to be given for such a kind of association is called Malaysia. It is a name used by the five Governments - three in the North Borneo territories controlled by British colonialists, one in Malaya and one in Singapore, backed by colonial agents. Sir, we must not be confused by the word "Malaysia". The British colonialists, the Tunku and the P.A.P. Government call it Malaysia, for it is the term used in this form of association. But, on the other hand, the P.A.P. call this form of association between Singapore and the Federation as merger. It is, therefore, clearly seen or understood that merger is part of Malaysia. The people must understand that merger is Malaysia and Malaysia is merger. These are two separate names but they mean the same. It is not a real merger or a real Malaysia; It is just a proposal, a plan, or, better still, it is a conspiracy of one country or countries to deprive the rights of the people of the other country and to seek control of the other country. It is also a plot of the colonialists to transfer a portion of their powers to the pro-colonialists who are local people. The colonialists make use of these people to suppress the people.

    Sir, as the proverb says, "lend the knife to kill the people - Chieh Tao Sha Ren." Sir, it means that I lend you a knife and you kill my enemy. If anyone wants to take revenge, then it is you who are going to be killed and not I. Sir, the British are not as silly as the ass. They know how to give; they know how to take; and not when to give and when to take. The British are not like the Dutch, the Portuguese or the French. They know how to train local people to do the work in the interests of the British colonialists. Sir, just imagine, will the British colonialists give something for nothing? How can we expect the British colonialists to

Column: 751

surrender the powers in Singapore and the three North Borneo territories to the local people for nothing?

    Sir, Singapore is just like an unsinkable aircraft-carrier of the British in the Far East and the mineral wealth in the three North Borneo territories is vital to the British. And yet we see the British supporting Malaysia, whereby the four territories of the British colonies are to be handed to Malaya, not for nothing, but for many things. Sir, with this change of authority from the British to the so-called great nationalists of Malaya, the people of these four territories will still have to pass their lives in darkness. They will still not be able to enjoy the democracy and freedom which they are now fighting to get from the British colonialists. Why do the British colonialists support Malaysia? Because the people in these four territories are fighting against the British and trying to free themselves from British rule. The British are now afraid. They are afraid because the lesser the British colonies the weaker the British become. The best and simplest way to prevent it from happening is to bring up and to train a pro-colonial force of local people and to strengthen and prolong British colonial rule. The British have trained and have brought them up in such a way that the interests of these people are inter-related. Sir, when I say the interests of these people, I mean the interests of the British colonialists and the interests of the pro-colonial agents who are local people. The survival of these people depends on one another. But the British are cleverer than those pro-colonial agents who claim themselves to be nationalists. They make use of these against the mounting anti-colonial force.

    Sir, it is said that Malaysia was first proposed by the nationalists of Malaya many years ago. I must say the proposal was right because the proposal of a Malaysia Plan was a plan to unite all the people of the territories to fight against the British colonialists and to free themselves from colonial rule. The concept and idea of the proposed Malaysia Plan at that time was to

Column: 752

mobilise the forces of anti-colonial and suppressed people to free themselves and to rule themselves. This plan was not supported by the British colonialists then. But now we see the present Malaysia Plan is not only supported by reactionary forces but is also supported by the British colonialists. Sir, even worse, this Malaysia Plan is not going to bring about the reunification of the territories and to unite these people, but to split these people into various categories with different types of citizenship and enjoying different privileges. In addition to this, the destiny of the people of the four territories at this moment is still under the control of the British. How could the cruel-hearted colonialists hand over their rice-bowl to the people of the colonies? And yet we see the colonialists trying to hand over the rice bowl as if to the people, but, in fact, to their pro-colonial agents so that they can share the benefits at the expense of the people whom they have colonised. How can we prove that the British colonialists have recruited a force of pro-colonial agents who work on their behalf? Sir, in the colonial regime, we saw the colonialists accusing the people as subversives, and yet the people fought against the British colonialists. Now, we see the people's elected government of the P.A.P. using the same tactics as those used by the British colonialists.

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): That is the trouble. We did not do that.

    Mr Teo Hock Guan: Sir, the British are very clever and cunning. Clever in that they know how to give and how to take. Cunning in that they know how to manipulate their pro-colonial agents.

    The Prime Minister: So you admitted you were cheated.

    Mr Teo Hock Guan: Sir, how silly the P.A.P. Government argue by saying that we are pro-colonial and they are anti-colonial and nationalists. And yet these so-called nationalists, the British love them and do not want to arrest them. They accuse our Barisan leaders

Column: 753

as pro-colonial, but the British once arrested them and put them in gaol.

    The Prime Minister: They invited them to Eden Hall.

    Mr Teo Hock Guan: Sir, as I was saying yesterday, the Prime Minister was very happy to see the Member for Anson move his amendment and he supported it. He was even happier to see the Member for Hong Lim support the amendment, even though these two speakers strongly oppose and condemn the merger proposals as laid down in the White Paper. Sir, the people think that the White Paper on merger and Malaysia mean the same thing - That is, merger means Malaysia and Malaysia means merger. Why was the Prime Minister so happy even though these two speakers attacked the P.A.P. merger? The answer is simple. It is because these two speakers have fallen into the P.A.P. propaganda trap and are now confusing the people on this issue.

    Sir, the Workers' Party and the U.P.P. oppose the merger plan and yet they support the Malaysia plan. Sir, we are more aware of the cunning of the P.A.P. and its treacherous tactics. We in the Barisan will not fall into the P.A.P. trap. The P.A.P. are now trying to accuse us, who oppose the sell-out plan, as Communists or Communist stooges -

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Which you are.

    Mr Teo Hock Guan: - and call themselves nationalists or democrats. Sir, what are they doing to justify themselves as being democrats? Sir, we see them using the police force and troops against the workers. We see them using the whole machinery of the Government to suppress those -

    Mr Speaker: Order. Can the Member tell me how those remarks are related to the motion?

    Mr Teo Hock Guan: Sir, the so-called democrats and nationalists are, in fact, behaving like Fascists. The term

Column: 754

"nationalist" is merely a cloak to hide all their Fascist tendencies.

    The Minister for Culture (Mr S. Rajaratnam): If we were Fascists, you would not be here.

    Mr Teo Hock Guan: Sir, when debating any motion in this House affecting the stability or the interest of the P.A.P., you are sure to hear the word "Communist". Everytime any motion is debated in this House their attack is usually directed at the Barisan Sosialis.

    Sir, they call us Communists or Communist stooges. This is nothing but to mislead the people. They say that if Singapore is under the control of the Communists, then there is no freedom, democracy and jobs, and so on. But they have forgotten one important point, and that is, has Singapore ever been controlled by the Communists? The people do not know what a Communist is.

    An hon. Member: We all know.

    Mr Teo Hock Guan: The people of Singapore have not tasted, the sweetness or bitterness of the Communists, but the people of Singapore have tasted the bitterness of colonialism and the bitterness of the P.A.P. Government. Sir, in Singapore, we cannot see any Communists.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: We are seeing one now.

    Mr Teo Hock Guan: Sir, they are trying to tell the people that if Singapore is under the control of the Communist, then we have no freedom, but at this moment we have no freedom, no democracy.

    The Prime Minister: Then what are you doing here?

    Mr Speaker: Order.

    Mr Teo Hock Guan: They use suppressions, smears, threats and intimidation against the people and their political opponents. Why, Sir? These people, especially the Ministers of the P.A.P., do not contact the people. They are isolated in their cool, comfortable air-conditioned rooms and they do not know the people's thinking.

Column: 755



    Sir, the people do not care about the Communists, socialists or anything, but they do care whether their livelihood is better or worse. Sir, the people will only support those political leaders who really work for the interest of the people and not those who just use a smear campaign against their political opponents.

    Sir, the Government accuse us of being anti-nationalists because we oppose merger.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: You want self-government. That is why.

    Mr Teo Hock Guan: But I would like to tell them that the people do not care whether we are nationalists, socialists or Communists. The people will fight against those - as I said before - who exploit them, whether they are Communists, socialists, colonialists or anybody else.

    Sir, I would also like to advise them not to call those people who oppose the P.A.P. as Communists or Communist stooges.

    Sir, during the election, the P.A.P. classified the political forces of Singapore into five categories - Communists, Socialist Left, Lunatic Left, Right-wing opportunists, and colonialists.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Which one are you?

    Mr Teo Hock Guan: Now we see the Prime Minister accusing those whom he once called the Lunatic Left as Communists and the real Communists completely disappeared.

    Sir, in conclusion - this is very important - the Malaysia Plan is a plot and a conspiracy of the British colonialists to suppress the national liberation movement in South-East Asia.

2.54 p.m.

    Mr Ong Chang Sam (Choa Chu Kang)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, when the Prime Minster on the 25th of this month moved this motion on the Malaysia Plan, he gave this House - and his speech was reported in the newspapers and was broadcast over the radio - such special phrases: "Communists",

Column: 756

"Communist open front workers and organisations", "Communist manipulators to establish international Communism and to exercise Communist control". "Communists in the veil of democracy", "the armed struggle directed by foreigners", "the people and the masses mean Communists", "peace-loving and love for democracy are also the special characteristics of the Communists", and "the Barisan Sosialis is being controlled by the P.K.I."

    Mr Speaker, Sir, all such phrases have only been used this year. They were not used last year. In fact, under the Rendel Constitution, the people of Singapore had also been treated to such phrases which were used on those P.A.P. members who were then with the workers and students. What was the result? The Government of the Member for Cairnhill collapsed. One of his colleagues went to Ipoh to open up a mine. The colonial government also resorted to such tactics against the so-called Communist. Such Communist phrases were also used on the people under colonial rule. What was the result? The colonial rulers had to withdraw and succumb to the anti-colonial forces.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, when such phrases as Communism are used on the people, it is a sign of the ruling class being in a desperate position. When such Communist phrases are used on the people, it is also the time when the rulers are doing things like selling out Singapore, which cannot be told to the people. These facts can easily be traced in history. Furthermore, we have seen the collapse of the former Government. At the present moment, we can see the P.A.P. is adopting all ways and means to bring about special arrangements.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the Prime Minister, the Minister for Culture, the Minister for Finance, the Minister for Home Affairs and other Members in the Government, including some Members in the Opposition, have all accused the Barisan Sosialis as being an open front organisation of the Communists or as stooges of the Communists. This allegation was also made by the former Chief Minister of

Column: 757

the former Government on the people in the P.A.P. At that time, the Prime Minister spoke in defence of the P.A.P. and of himself. He also defended Mr Lim Ching Siong and his colleagues. He very forcefully attacked the then Government for using such means. This took place only four years ago. The present Prime Minister is using the same tactics which were used by the former Chief Minister against his political opponents. He has also put on the dirty gloves of the former Chief Minister to carry out his attack on his opponents.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, while debating this Malaysia plan, why should the P.A.P. Government especially shout "Communist"? What is the aim and meaning behind it? Is it a target against the Communists? Are they treating the Communists as their target of attack? I feel that I have a responsibility to let you, Mr Speaker, Sir, and the people in Malaysia and Singapore understand the whole situation. The answer to those questions is that the P.A.P. is shouting communist slogans to suppress the freedom of speech of the people and to confuse the vision of the people in order to achieve its own political ends.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to go further and give a clearer answer. No matter what phrases or what amendments we put forward to this Malaysia motion, such as the deletion of the words "in principle", "plan", and the insertion of the word "motion", no matter what we do about the phraseology of the motion, our position remains the same. Even if Singapore is included in the Malaysia Plan, its position will be the same as that envisaged in the proposals contained in Paper Cmd. 33 of 1961. I would like to make some motion of the correspondence contained in the White Paper.

    The Prime Minister of Singapore sent a letter to the Prime Minister of the Federation on 11th November, 1961.

    `You will recall that in our discussions on the constitutional framework to effect the merger of Singapore with the Federation of Malaya in the new Federation of Malaysia

Column: 758

we agreed upon a memorandum which contains several heads of agreement, including State and Federal responsibilities...'.

    On the same day the Prime Minister of the Federation replied to our Prime Minister. In the Tunku's reply, he said:

    `With reference to your letter of 11th November, 1961 ... you wrote as follows:

    "You will recall that in our discussions on the constitutional framework to effect the merger of Singapore with the Federation of Malaya in the new Federation of Malaysia we agreed upon a memorandum which contains several heads of agreement, including State and Federal responsibilities, whereby Singapore will retain responsibility over Education and Labour and enjoy local autonomy in certain agreed matters as set out therein, without prejudice to the basic principle that there should be a strong Central Government for the Federation of Malaysia as a whole.".'

    Mr Speaker, Sir, you can see clearly from this memorandum and letter that in the Greater Malaysia Plan, i.e. the Federation of Malaysia, Singapore must go in according to the conditions set out in this letter. Mr Speaker, Sir, under such a Malaysia Plan, what can Singapore citizens get? Singapore citizens will get no more than what is contained in the White Paper. In this White Paper, firstly, the 600,000-odd citizens of Singapore will not automatically become citizens of the Federation of Malaysia. They will only become nationals of Malaysia, which is of no practical use. Secondly, Singapore must hand over $100 million to the Central Government of the Federation of Malaysia. Thirdly, autonomy in labour is not safe-guarded because the Tunku has just said that after merger with the Federation, they will properly deal with the industrial disputes in Singapore. So the so-called autonomy in labour is nothing but nought. Fourthly, similar arguments can be applied to the so-called autonomy in education because the Federation Government will be able to deal with educational problems in the way it wishes to do in labour. Fifthly, economically the Central Government of Greater Malaysia has the last say in financial arrangements. Sixthly, Singapore citizens will not be able to enjoy equal rights as those citizens in Greater Malaysia. Therefore, Mr Speaker, Sir, whether you have a merger between

Column: 759

Singapore and the Federation, or whether you have a Greater Malaysia, Singapore citizens will get the same - half a pound or 8 ounces.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, although the White Paper on merger has been passed by this House, it does not mean that there is no dissatisfaction among the people. Even if the Government were to use propaganda media like the newspapers and the radio to deceive the people, and to try to cajole their brains in order to resort to all sorts of means so that they could control the freedom of speech and expression of the people, they would finally fail. And because they know that the people have decided to oppose all retrogressive constitutional arrangements, a national referendum will give the people an opportunity to make their own decision. But the P.A.P. Government are very clever. They have decided to shelve the National Referendum Bill for the time being.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, in the course of the debate on the present motion these past few days, ths House has heard many of these so-called Communist phrases. Such phrases also appear in the speeches reported in the newspapers, as though the speakers are heroes of anti-Communism. It is the aim of the P.A.P. Government to use the term "Communism" to divert the attention of the people and to suppress their expression of discontent against the Government. Mr Speaker, Sir, this is because the P.A.P. Government has made the allegation that only those who are Communists are opposed to Greater Malaysia. Under such circumstances, the Barisan Sosialis have been branded as an open front organisation of the Communists and a stooge of the Communists. Some people have been branded as Communists; even the word "masses" has been described as Communistic. So their argument is that all those who are opposed to the Greater Malaysia Plan are Communists, irrespective of whether they are citizens or not. The people of Sarawak are opposed to the Greater Malaysia Plan, and so, according to their argument, the Government can call them Communists. The people of Brunei are also opposed to the

Column: 760

Greater Malaysia Plan. So the Government brand them as Communists. In short, all those who are opposed to the Greater Malaysia Plan are Communists.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, in this series of propaganda moves, who have the guts to speak their own minds? Civic organisations do not have the courage to express their own views. The Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce will not hold another forum on Greater Malaysia. Will the workers, the farmers, the hawkers, the merchants, the teachers, the students, etc, have the guts to express their disagreement? If you should, in the dark, express any disagreement, you will also be called a Communist. So in this way the P.A.P. Government will be able to divert the attention of the people so that they could easily push forward the Malaysia Plan. Under very high-sounding names, they are trying to push through a merger between Singapore and the Federation. Finally, the P.A.P. has an aim to achieve, but it is after the attainment of this aim that the livelihood of the people will be uncertain and in danger.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, when a quack doctor tells you that you are suffering from a serious disease, that is the time when he tries to sell you quack medicine. When a pickpocket touches your body, that is the time when you will miss your purse or wallet. When the P.A.P. Government shouts that all the streets in Singapore are full of Communists, well that is exactly the time when the P.A.P. is facing political bankruptcy.

    I hope that the people of Singapore will be able to increase their own vigilance. Otherwise they will not be able to see through the sinister moves and words of the P.A.P. The people should not be intimidated by threats and the propaganda of the P.A.P. Then they will not fall into the trap of the P.A.P.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, if we the Barisan Sosialis were to support this motion on Greater Malaysia, then it would be tantamount to accepting the White Paper on merger. We do not want to see the basic rights of the people of Singapore being reduced. We are not afraid of

Column: 761

being branded as Communists by the leadership of the P.A.P. We will not be coerced into accepting this motion.

    Mr Speaker, we want to be friends with the people. We do not like to be the public enemy of the people. Neither do we want to be traitors to socialism. Mr Speaker, Sir, as long as it is in the interest of the people, we, in the Barisan Sosialis, will struggle and fight to the bitter end. I would like to tell the Prime Minister, the Minister for Finance and the Minister for Culture that the people in Malaysia have seen through their game in dealing with the Communists. As far as we are concerned, these tactics are not new.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the so-called non-Communist socialist P.A.P. is at present becoming anti-Communist. They are progressively and positively anti-Communist. It is definite. There is no point in our arguing over this. When a political Party is facing bankruptcy in its political philosophy, then its political arguments will be illogical. The P.A.P. says, on the one hand, that we, the Barisan Sosialis, are the Dutchmen. On the other hand, they say that the Barisan Sosialis are connected with the P.K.I. So if we carry this argument one step further, then the P.K.I. are the Dutch and the Dutch are also the P.K.I.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, can you say that such an argument of the P.A.P. is rational? I will say no. Even primary school students will agree with me. And so, Mr Speaker, Sir, our proper and correct conclusion is that the Barisan Sosialis are not Communists. Neither are the Barisan Sosialis Dutch.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, when the Government under the Member for Cairnhill was about to collapse, one of his colleagues, Chew Swee Kee, accused the students of being Communist for using the word "Hsueh-hsih" in Mandarin, which means study. Now the P.A.P. are using the same tactics. They are saying that those who use words like "cho tse" meaning to organise; "ren ming", meaning people; "chin chung" meaning masses; are Communists. They say that

Column: 762

all such terms are typical of the Communists. According to this logic, then the Minister for Home Affairs, who is the Organising Secretary of the P.A.P., should also be a Communist because "people" is being used in the name of the P.A.P. Can we say then that the P.A.P. is also Communist? In the P.A.P. there is a Board of People's Work. Can we call this organisation a Communist organisation? The Ministry of Culture has published a pamphlet entitled "Peaceful revolution". Can we also call this a Communist revolution? Mr Speaker, Sir, yesterday, I went to the library of this Assembly and looked up all the dictionaries and encyclopaedia. But I was unable to find which definitions are monopolised by the Communists. I would like to suggest to the Minister for Culture that he should direct the Minister for Education to stop all the schools from using terms which they call Communistic. Otherwise all the students of the various races will be termed Communists.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, ordinarily any talk on economics should have been made by the Minister for Finance. But when we were debating the motion on Greater Malaysia, the economic aspects of this plan were touched upon at great length by the Minister for Culture. He said that after the realisation of Malaysia the five territories would enjoy economic prosperity and the livelihood of the people would be improved. The Minister for Culture also talked at great length on the activities of the Communists. We can see very clearly from this that the economic theories of the Minister for Culture cannot stand refutation. No wonder the Minister for Finance dare not say anything on that. The Minister for Culture was only trying to draw a picture of a cake on a piece of paper and telling the people of the five territories that they can eat it. He was thus thinking these people would be fooled and trapped by his intriques.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, in the speech made by the Minister for Culture, he touched on the economic benefits of Malaysia. The most salient point in his speech is that only when the five territories are merged together will there be economic

Column: 763

stability. If the five territories were independent of one another, then there would have to be separate currencies. There would have to be a separate economic system which would be competing against one another. Moreover, without a reunification of the five territories, there could not be any industrialisation.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the extent of economic stability, judging from the present economic situation of the five territories, does not depend on the size of the territories but on the internal resources of each territory. Economic stability depends on prices and also on international supply and demand. If the prices of tin and rubber were to decrease day after day, does it mean that after the merger of the five territories the economic situation would be better?

    Mr Speaker, Sir, after the five territories have merged together to form one nation, does it mean that the five territories should have a unified currency system before we can have economic stability and prosperity? I do not agree with this view. The most important thing, when speaking on these economic problems, is this. The five territories were once controlled by the British colonialists. When they become independent, they could also become members of the British Commonwealth, and in the British Commonwealth there is one economic system. Different systems of currency are not a decisive factor in the determination of the economic stability of the five territories. After these five territories are independent, they can form a common market and resolve all these economic problems. We can learn a lesson from the present European Common Market. We can find examples in their system. For instance, the franc is used by the French; the mark is used by West Germany, and the peso is used by Italy. All these different forms of currency are used by the Common Market countries. When in future the United Kingdom also joins the Common Market, the British pound will also be One of the currencies used. The currencies used in these Common Market countries are all different. But in spite of that, they can form a common market. This goes
